title: Is a will made before marriage valid in California and are stocks brought into the marriage community property?
question: A will was made 3 years prior to a marriage and never updated with the spouse information. Is that will still valid or does it become invalid and everything falls under community propery law?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Wills and estates,Estates,Estate property,Rights of survivorship and estate planning,Wills,Community property and wills,Intestacy and probate
answers:
The will is still valid, but a surviving spouse can opt to take what would have been his or her intestate share (all of the community property, plus all, half, or one-third of the separate property of the deceased spouse, depending on the survivors).

I'm not sure what you mean by 'joint ownership.' If the real property was held as joint tenants with right of survivorship, then the real property goes to the surviving joint tenant. If the property was held as tenants in common, it will need to be determined if it was community property or not - where did the money come from to purchase the property? Same with stocks. Review the fact pattern with a local probate attorney to answer those questions.

A spouse from a marriage after a will is drawn can make a claim in California to a share of the estate and take against the will. The will does not fail because of the later marriage but the omitted spouse is allowed to claim against the estate. As to the real estate, if it is held as joint tenants, by operation of law, the surviving spouse gets 100% of the property. If it is held as community property only, then, yes, the deceased spouse may leave his half as s/he chooses.

Generally, in community property states, money earned by either spouse during marriage and all property bought with those earnings are considered community property that is owned equally by husband and wife. Likewise, debts incurred during marriage are generally debts of the couple. At the death of one spouse, his half of the community property goes to the surviving spouse unless he left a will that directs otherwise. Married people can still own separate property. For example, property inherited by just one spouse belongs to that spouse alone. A spouse can leave separate property to anyone; it doesn't have to go to the surviving spouse. If the stock was prior to marriage, it is separate property and the income from it remains separate property so it can be left as the deceased spouse directs.

If your spouse is alive, you should both have new wills or a Trust drawn up to avoid problems down the road. Be clear though, separate property of your spouse does not become your property on his or her death unless that is what he or she directs.
